LEBANON DISPATCH

A Nation Whose Only Certainty Is Uncertainty

By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD BINT JBEIL, Lebanon - The
town in south Lebanon appeared
deserted its roads deserted, its roads empty and its
market shuttered, after months of fighting between Hezbollah and Israel across the nearby
border made many residents
But in a central square this summer, Hezbollah had erected
huge banners for the triple funeral of a man the militant group neral of a man the minttant grou
claimed a its own and his two
sisters, all killed when Israel sisters, all killed when Israel
bombed their home in this south bombed their home in
ern town of Bint Jbeil.
As the coffins arrived, martial music blared and a few hundred
of the remaining residents came

As Hezbollah and Israel Extend Their Fight, Anxiety Spreads
to pay their respects. Watching the procession,
Asmaa Alawiyeh, an accountant, said life was hard after montths of
clashes. Her two children were clashes. Her two children wer
out of school. Her husband, a plumber, could not find work. And no one knew when life "There is no plan", said Ms. "There is no plan," said Ms.
Alawiyeh, 32 . "We have no idea what to prepare for because we Since the what's coming."
fighting a second, smaller battle
along the Lebanon-Israel border to bog down Israeli forces and help Hamas, its ally in Gaza. The

tries, leaving the border zone dotted with rubble-strewed ghost towns. Now, fear has spread that a Now, fear has spread that a

MINNESOTA'S WALZ IS HARRIS'S CHOICE FOR RUNNING MATE

With Plain-Spoken Criticism of Trump, Governor Eclipses Bigger Names

This article is by Reid J. Epstein, Katie Rogers, Erica L. Green and
Shane Goldmacher. Shane Goldmacher.
WASHINGTON - Vice President Kamala Harris, the Demo-
cratic nominee for president, chase Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate on Tuesday,
elevating a former football coach elevating a former football coach
whose rural roots, liberal policies whose rural roots, liberal policies
and buzzy takedowns of former
President Donald J. Trump have President Donald J. Trump have
recently put him on the map. recently put him on the map.
Mr. Walz, 60 , emerged from a
fied field of candidatas who had better name recognition and more politi-
cally advantageous home states. cally advantageous home states.
Minnesota is not a top-tier presidential battleground and is un-
dikely dential to prove critical to a Harris-
Walz victory. Walz victory.
But he jumped to the top of Ms. Harris's list in a matter of days,
helped by cable news appearhelped in cable news appear-
ances in which he declared that Republicans were "weird." The new, clear articulation of why vot-
ers should reject Mr. Trump ers should reject Mr. Trump
caught on fast and turned the spotlight on the plain-spoken Midwesterner behind it.
"One of the things that stood out
to me about Tim is how his convicto me about Tim is how his convic-
tions on fighting for middle class tions on fighting for middle class
families run deep," Ms. Harris said in a social media post con-
firming his selection. "It's person-
al." Mr. Walz (pronounced Walls) appeared with Ms. Harris at a rally on Tuestay evening in Phila-
delphia, their first appearance as
the Democratic ticket. In his own post on social media, Mr. Walz
said it was the "honor of a lifesaid it was the "honor of a life-
time" to be chosen as her running mate.
"Vice President Harris is show-
ing us the politics of what's possible. It reminds me a bit of the firs

Tests the Boundaries of Inclusion
Mr. Walz leapfrogged better-
known contendersin partbecause Ms. Harris viewed him part becaus an r. Harris viewed him as an Ev
eryman figure from Minnesota whose Midwestern-dad vibe balnced out her Bay Area background, according to three people
familiar with the vice president's thinking.
With his straight-talking style,
Mr. Walz was thought to se somes Mr. Walz was thought to be some one who could match up well in
debate against Senator JD Vance of Ohio, whom Mr. Trump chose ast month as his running mate. And after two weeks of vettin
nd deliberations, Ms. Harris con nected best with Mr. Walz in comDarison with the other choices. Over and over in the selection
process, loyalty had been emphasized as one of the most important criteria for Harris. This suggests
that Mr. Walz convinced her he would support her not only in win-
ning but also in helping her govIn her social media post, Ms Harris highlighted Mr. Walz's bigraphy as a National Guards mancher, football coach and adviser of the Gay-Straight Alliance.
She also pointed to his efforts as governor to work with Republicans on bipartisan measures hile pushing progressive prior Mr. Walz is in his second term a

By DAN BARRY
LINO LAKES, Minn. - Butch
Robinson is done. After dedicating
most of his 77 years to growing
sod, he just wants to sell his
sprawi oo green and ease his
aching back into the lounge chair
of a hard-earned retirement.
That is why Mr. Robinson and
the two sons who runt the family
farm with him, both with nagging
backs, were delighted when a de-
veloper put down a nonrefundable

Rolling sod on the Robinsons' farm in Lino Lakes, Minn.
hem. Scowling like a principal an ticipating school-assembly misbe havior, the mayor expressed hope Then everyone stood to pledge allegiance to one nation, under
God, with liberty and justice for
 Harold Robinson isn't sure how he became "Butch," but the nick-
name has stuck for decades, jus as he's been stuck in pretty much the only place he's ever known.
His father and an uncle bougt the land in the 1940s and turned the wiregrass fields into a farm for vegetables and, eventually, sod For many years, Butch Robinson
lived here with his parents and three siblings in a small hom with an outhouse and an un obstructed vi
all," he said.
